question_parts.text: What is AI? Explain four approaches of AI.
What do you mean by acting rationally? What is a rational agent?
Briefly explain any four state-of-the-art applications of Al.
Write how a basic agent can be converted to an autonomous agent.
Explain the capabilities a system should posses to qualify for Total Turing Test.
What is the difference between uninformed and informed search strategies? List at least three search strategies from each.
Are reflex actions (e.g. flinching from a hot stove) rational? Are they intelligent?

What is a vacuum cleaner agent? Draw state space diagram of a very basic vacuum cleaner with just two adjacent square locations: (A & B) and three actions : (moving right (R), moving left (L) and sucking the dirt in one go (S))

questions.full_question_text_for_embedding: 2018 Autumn End Semester Artificial Intelligence (CS-3028) General: Question 1: (a) What is AI? Explain four approaches of AI. (b) What do you mean by acting rationally? What is a rational agent? (c) Briefly explain any four state-of-the-art applications of Al. (d) Write how a basic agent can be converted to an autonomous agent. (e) Explain the capabilities a system should posses to qualify for Total Turing Test. (f) What is the difference between uninformed and informed search strategies? List at least three search strategies from each. (g) Are reflex actions (e.g. flinching from a hot stove) rational? Are they intelligent? (h) What is a vacuum cleaner agent? Draw state space diagram of a very basic vacuum cleaner with just two adjacent square locations: (A & B) and three actions : (moving right (R), moving left (L) and sucking the dirt in one go (S))

question_parts.text: In A’ search, define the admissible heuristic and consistent heuristic. How do these two heuristics are associated with the optimality of A* search?

Apply A* search to expand the nodes systematically by drawing the corresponding tree diagrams. Find the order of expansion of nodes from start state to goal state. (18) (38) (35) (16) Under which condition, Depth first search fails? Explain how Depth limited search (DLS) takes care of this issue of DFS. What is the major drawback of DLS? Show in a tabular manner the comparative performance measures of six uninformed search strategies, such as, BFS, UCS, DFS, DLS, IDS and BDS. Justify why the time & space complexities of Bidirectional search (BDS) being implemented from both ends using BFS are considerably less than those of Breadth first search (BFS) being implemented only from initial end, for the given initial state and goal state. Find the order of expansion of nodes for the following search graph using i) Uniform cost search (UCS) ii) Greedy best first search Assume start node to be S and goal node to be G. The values indicated along the connecting lines represent step costs or transition costs and values indicated inside the nodes represent heuristic values.
